2. And for this reason he was named
Anthropographus (that is, painter of Men).
For even if one can reasonably
depict the parts of the Human body,
and all that belongs to it,
to be familiar with everything is more praised:
so then to be an exceptional
painter, one must be skilled in all things.
left-middleThat one should seek to be universal.

3. We may begin our education at once,
by turning to tame Beasts.
First, the noblest of the Cattle, of great worth,
Then to the helpful courageous Horses,
Noble (I say), because there are many qualities
to be found in Horses, they are like Dogs,
Being true to their Master and loving him.
Their free, high disposition cannot be overcome.

4. The Horse scorns fear, indeed, he goes to meet
the armored company, bold, unthinking,
not fleeing the sword, pawing the ground;
like the Hart, he senses the battle,
hearing the sound of the clear trumpet,
gentle play entertains him, he is docile yet powerful,
and fleet as the Wind (as Poets say).
He learns to honor his Master and bow before him.

5. Caesar Dictator’s Horse
let no one ride him except his Lord,
King Nicomedes’ Horse in ancient times
died of starvation on the death of his Lord;
Another, having committed the abomination of incest
with his mother, was so sorrowful that,
once the blindfold was removed from his eyes
leaped to his death from a mountain.
left-middleExamples of the character of Horses

6. Shall I tell of the Horse of the Scythian King
who killed his Lord’s murderer?
Or the Horse of Centaretus, who threw himself
off a rock with Antiochus on his back, in revenge,
to make him pay for the death of his master–
shall I be silent? And of Bucephalus,
who did such wondrous things, one and another,
that Alexander named his tomb and a City for him?

7. Indeed, I will pass over all of this,
so as not to waver from my intention.
Indeed, more fitting here is the book
which Pliny himself devotes to the Tournament of Horses,
where he described everything that cultivates
the fine Form of a Horse (as he said).
This book seems to be gnawed by the teeth of age,
